ovdesc.p: This table is used to define the types of Limit to be processed by
the Limit System. Each Limit type (known as a Limit Reference within
the System) can be defined as being part of a hierarchy, made up of
a GLOBAL Limit, PRODUCT Limit and SUB PRODUCT Limit.
This table is also used for define whether the Limit Reference is one
that requires checking each time, or whether it is updated only for information.
See the helptext on the record id for more details

desc.p: With this structure, the user can define up to 999 different
types of Global Line, 99 different types of Product Limit
and 99 different types of Sub-product Limit.
The relation between records is hierarchical, the Global is
the higest level and a sub-product of level 9 is the lowest.
LIMIT records use both the original LIMIT.REFERENCES as well
as combining them. For example where a Global Limit of
100000 is defined witha product of say 10000. Then a LIMIT
can refer to 110000 (i.e 100000 plus 10000). Additionally
where sub-products exist under 10000 (say 1000 and 2000)
this could result in LIMIT records with references such as:
100000 Global Limit
110000 Global Limit + Product
111000 Global Limit + Product + Sub-Product
112000 Global Limit + Product + Sub-Product
3 to 7 numeric characters.
in the following format: 'GGG PPSS' where: GGG
=identification of a Global line (range = 10000, 20000
... 9990000) PP =identification of the Product number
(range = 100, 200 ... to 9900) SS =identification of
Sub-Product number (e.g. 101, 102 ... 9999)
Mandatory Input.
Reversal not allowed if used in LIMIT.PARAMETER
Reversal not allowed if used in LIMIT

The level of the sub-product being defined.
Up to 9 sub product levels can be defined below the standard
sub product level. A standard sub-product can be identified
by the last two characters of the limit reference being
anything other than zeros.
Sub-product levels 1 to 9 are allowed. With 1 representing
the highest and 9 the lowest sub product levels.
Example Product & Sub-Product:
We need a Limit structure to cover generic Loans that is
sub-divided into those to Banks and those to Non-Banks. This
requires a Product and two sub-products.
We define:
5000 - product for Loans
5010 - sub-product for Loans to Banks
5020 - sub-product for Loans to Non-Banks
Example Product, Sub-Product & Sub-product levels:
We need a Limit structure to cover generic Loans that is
sub-divided into those to Banks and those to Non-Banks. Each
of these needs to be split into secured & non-secured.
The secured level also needs to be split between secured by
property; secured by cash & secured other. This requires
a Product; two sub-products, two sub-products at level 1 and
six sub-products at level 2.
We define:
6000 - product for Loans
6010 - sub-product for Loans to Banks
6011 - secured (level 1)
6012 - secured by property (level 2)
6013 - secured by cash (level 2)
6014 - secured other (level 2)
6020 - sub-product for Loans to Non-Banks
6011 - secured (level 1)
6012 - secured by property (level 2)
6013 - secured by cash (level 2)
6014 - secured other (level 2)

Determines how the percentage amount will be derived from the
MATURITY.PERIOD and MAT.PERIOD.PERC fields.
This field can contain one of three values.
The keyword PRORATA in this field indicates that the
calculation will be pro rata according to the time remaining
to maturity or the length of a MATURITY.PERIOD.BAND.
For pro rata the calculation will be;
% x days to maturity / 365
with the annual period always in days.
The keyword PERIOD indicates that the calculation will be
prorata according to the time remaining to maturity or the
length of a MATURITY.PERIOD.BAND.
The pro rata calculation for the PERIOD setting will be:
% x period to maturity / period
where period is set according to the MATURITY.BAND.DEFINITION
i.e in Days (D) Weeks (W) Months(M) Years (Y) Where a period
is a fraction of a band this will be rounded up.
When the word FIXED is indicated the calculation will not be
pro rata and is calculated as a simple percentage.
When PRORATA or PERIOD is used with LEVEL structure, the
relevant percentage derived for the remaining contract
period will be applied.
When PRORATA or PERIOD is used with a BANDED structure, each
percentage band falling within the remaining contract period
will be applied for the period of the that band.
A PRORATA/PERIOD method can result in a total percentage
taken which is in excess of 100% of the transaction value.
This can be limited by use of the PERCENTAGE.CAP field.

Indicates whether, or not, a type of Limit regains its
original value on liquidation or repayment of a utilisation
(drawdown etc...) The alternative terminology, revolving
(non-reducing) and non-revolving (reducing), is sometimes used.
A reducing LIMIT can start as USD1million and have USD500T
drawn. When the drawing matures the LIMIT will be USD500T.
However, if it was a non-reducing LIMIT the amount available
would be re-instated to USD1million.
NB When the user is creating a 'GLOBAL' Limit
Reference type, the system will make sure that the value of

words, if the Global line is defined as a Non Reducing Limit
type, all the Children (REFERENCE CHILD) defined under this
Global Line must also have been defined as 'Non
Reducing'. The same is true for product and sub-product relationships.

Specifies the rate to be used in the revaluation of the limit
outstanding when the limit and the transaction are in
different currencies. The rate specified in this field will
be used for the revaluation of the limit outstanding using
this reference provided the field UPDATE. RATE in LIMIT.
PARAMETER has a value of Yes. Any rate specified in this
field will be ignored and only the mid rate will be used in
the revaluation of limit outstanding if the field UPDATE.
RATE in LIMIT. PARAMETER has a value of No.
If the field is Null, only the mid rate will be used in the
revaluation of the limit outstanding.
Values allowed are;
BUY-BUY, BUY-MID, BUY-SEL, MID-BUY, MID-MID, MID-SEL,
SEL-BUY, SEL-MID and SEL-SEL
Any of the above rates will not be applicable if the LIMIT
and the transaction are both in LCY or in the same currency.
Example
In LIMIT. PARAMETER field UPDATE. RATE is Yes. The limit
reference used is 400 in which CONVERT. RATE is BUY-SEL.
CASE1
Limit XXXXXX.400.01 is in LCY (Say USD). A contract for
USD100000 is put through to hit the limit. In this case
since both limit and the transactions are in LCY there is no
conversion involved and therefore the limit outstanding will
be updated with -100000.
CASE2
A contract for GBP100000 is put through to hit the limit
given in case1. Here the transaction in GBP will be
converted to LCY which is also the limit currency, using the
first component of the CONVERT. RATE specified in the limit
reference 400 which in this case is the BUY rate of the
transaction currency. If the Buy rate for GBP is 1.50 then
the limit outstanding will be up dated by
-150000(100000*1.50) and the total outstanding in the limit
after this transaction will be -100000-150000= -250000.
CASE3
Limit YYYYYY.400.01 is in EUR. A contract for GBP100000 is
put through to hit this limit. BUY rate of GBP=1.50 Sell
rate of EUR=1.20.In this case the transaction in GBP will be
converted to USD by using the first component of the
CONVERT. RATE which is BUY. This amount will be converted to
EUR which is the limit currency, using the second component
of the CONVERT. RATE which is SEL. So the limit outstanding
will be calculated using the formula 100000*1.50/1.20=125000(EUR)
However in a Limit structure the rate specified in the lowest
limit reference used will be taken for updating the
outstanding in the higher limits in the hierarchy.
For example Limit reference 400 has 410, 420 and 430 as a
child references.
400-CONVERT. RATE-BUY-BUY
410- CONVERT. RATE-BUY-SEL
420-CONVERT. RATE-BUY-MID
430-CONVERT. RATE-SEL-BUY
When 410 is used to hit the limit structure, only BUY-SEL
specified in 410 will be used for updating the out standings
in both 400 & 410.
When 420 is used to hit the limit structure, only BUY-MID
specified in 420 will be used for updating the out standings
in both 400 & 420.
When 430 is used to hit the limit structure, only SEL-BUY
specified in 430 will be used for updating the out standings
in both 400 & 430.
Optional
Values allowed are BUY-BUY, BUY-MID, BUY-SEL, MID-BUY,
MID-MID, MID-SEL, SEL-BUY, SEL-MID and SEL-SEL

Specifies the type of a Limit Reference in a Cross Limit
structure i.e. whether a PRODUCT or a CROSS or a SUB-PRODUCT
Limit Reference.
In a Cross Limit structure, a Limit Reference specified as a
valid record key in the application LIMIT.CROSS.PARAM would
be a PRODUCT Limit Reference; Limit References with values
less than or equal to the value of the field TOP.CROSS.REF
in the LIMIT.CROSS.PARAM record for the Product, would be a
CROSS Limit Reference. Limit Reference with a value greater
than the value of the field TOP.CROSS.REF would be a
SUB-PRODUCT Limit Reference.
For example, in the LIMIT.CROSS.PARAM record with key: 8200,
the value of TOP.CROSS.REF is 8219.
Then the value of CROSS.LIMIT in the PRODUCT Limit Reference
8200 would be TOP.
The value of CROSS.LIMIT in CROSS Limit References i.e. with
Key value between 8201 and 8219 would be CROSS.
The value of CROSS.LIMIT in SUB-PRDOCUT Limit References
i.e. with Key value between 8220 and 8299 would be PROD.
Updated by the System.
For PRODUCT, CROSS and SUB-PRODUCT Limit References, the
value would be updated respectively as TOP, CROSS and PROD.
Specifies whether the Limit Reference is one which requires
checking, and whether limit overrides are required, when
Limit records are created by default.
When a new LIMIT is created by default, the value used in the
field CHECK.LIMIT is derived from this field. For Limits
which record data for information only, such as deposits and
Fiduciary Placements, this field should be set to
'NO' to prevent overrides being generated.
If SUPPRESS is selected, then limit processing will not be done.
This can be selected when credit risk is checked by external system.
In this case limit will be used only for information purpose.
